commentBody: Entertaining! I found THIS THAT AND THE OTHER pretty easily but had some trouble coming up with the Edsels' song. I did enjoy Simeon's original clue for that one. I don't care much for roller coasters (and especially not upside-down ones) but I had fun with them in the puzzle.
I can’t see the circles using the Games app on my iPhone. I looked at the column halfway through the puzzle, which I normally don’t do, and realized I was missing a visual cue.
I am so sick and tired of NYT using puzzle designs that don’t work on its digital platform. Come on, you can do better.
I managed to solve this, but I’m more than a little fed up with the app giving no indication what’s going on. Again. This just isn’t fair.

Have you ever done a traffic rotary going around twice before you figured out where to exit?

Yeah no, me neither.

But if I ever do, I’ll know what to cry out to the other confused motorists:

RAMA LAMA LAMA DING DONG DONG!

(P.S. adding this puzzle to my faves of 2024 list!)
This one won't print. Is that because of the dumb circles? I'm going to pass on this. I'll give the crossword people one a week.
A clever but rewarding challenge.  My biggest difficulty was landing on "nega" as a prefix.
Genuinely clever.  Worth solving.

Had absolutely no idea what was going on and managed to solve only by sheer dumb luck (and the grace of crosses). There were no circles on my iPhone and yes, I checked to make sure overlays were on. I usually hate it when people complain about these things but man, that was disappointing and frustrating.

Even if I could see the circles (which I cannot on my iPad), I probably would not get the other two answers. I see “whetimes” but can’t figure out which other answers need to be looped in, and have no clue about the third. Thus, not a very satisfying puzzle.

I think this is my favorite puzzle of the year so far! So clever — this is one of those that confirm I could never create a good crossword puzzle because HOW do you come up with this???!???

Sorry to hear about the technical difficulties some were having :( definitely very frustrating & I always feel horrible for the constructor!

I love me a Simeon Siegel puzzle and expected trickery. Trickery there was, but I solved everything without understanding just how the looping worked in the highlighted theme entries. 

Decided to read the column.

“Ohhh, circles!”

“Wait. What circles?”

[in the tone reserved for Señor Gato when he chanced the kitchen counter] “Again, NYT?”

I was surprised that there were two loops per theme answer- and the directions changed, first answer an “up” loop, then a “down“ loop, the next reversed to down and up, and the third as the first- interesting symmetry.  “We need symmetry for life itself.”
Great puzzle! I played on Galaxy phone and saw the circles fine.
You’d think that people as clever with words as the NYT puzzle team could write a description of features that don’t display properly on app versions of the puzzle.  This is waaay overdue for a fix.

Had SETTLE for "Resolve" and kept thinking, "SYMAN" who says that as a brotherly greeting except maybe Simeon's brother, if he has one, playing on his name. And then it dawned on me. Also liked the double meaning of "Masters" in the cross of PGA and GRE (which I had as GPA for a time, too). I rue the day when LIV will be the answer to a golf clue. 

I love the loop de loops! Really clever idea and perfect execution, and also admired the choice to put them from the middle upwards -- no self respecting coaster has 'em at the bottom -- and in fact we purists in Pittsburgh who grew up going to Kennywood, an amusement park in Pittsburgh featuring world class straight up (and down) roller coasters -- The Thunderbolt (NYT #1 coaster in the country, 1974), Phantom's Revenge (in its time the fastest in the world with the longest drop) and the Steel Curtain (a "hypercoaster" meaning it has a drop of at least 200 ft) -- were taught to look upon the new generation of coasters with loop-de-loops and corkscrews as rude upstarts, churlish, somehow phony and not in keeping with the spirit of roller coasters. But De gustibus non spituputandum, right? Which translates as, Your taste in nausea may vary. 

Rama lama ding dong. The title itself is an earworm, it's going to be playing in an endless loop de loop for hours...

Had to employ my SPIDEY sense to help solve this Simeon Siegel special. The song for today's theme is by the great Billy Preston, performing it it here with Ringo and an iteration of his All Starr Band. https://youtu.be/-fZMwtkfVCA?si=RmvNUgp6SoW9E1yx

Hi everyone,

Sorry about the overlay. I’ve reported it, and it probably will be fixed tomorrow. 

For now, please try turning “Show Overlay” ON in your settings. It may not work for those solving in the iOS app, but it may help others who have it turned off by default.

I also suffered from the SETTLE METTLE thing - not sure if that was very clever or serendipity on the part of the constructor.  Some wonderful clues - the best drivers, the opening line, the sweaty exercise. 64A could have been NIT or NET (a hair net can be scratchy - ask me how I know!) and I have to admit that I'm a little puzzled by 36D.  I recall in the first Star Wars the robots were R2D2 and C-3PO; so I can see how Artoo arose but not THREEPIO.  

All in all very satisfying and well over my Thursday mean.

This one had my head spinning at first, but turned out not to be more fun than a rollercoaster.  I was able to see the circles, and avoided words intersecting with them until I had enough other answers to feel comfortable that the trickery did not involve anything more than entering the right letter in the right square.  I caught on to the LOOPDELOOP aspect before I hit the revealer because RAMALAMADINGDONG was a gimme for me.  I made a few small mistakes, (e.g., nonpc, rather than NOTPC and sui before ECO), but finished in a reasonable time.  I do feel lucky that I haven’t yet had any problems  with technical issues like seeing the circles today, or shaded squares etc.  I’m sure I’d be frustrated if those visuals were absent.
I had problems with the METTLE word as well, but not from the first letter.  MY MAN was a helpful cross, but I had ACT AS ONE instead of ACT ALONE, and that one letter threw me off a bit.

If you are going to use clues that reference 1/3,600th of a degree you should acknowledge any two dimensional loop-de-loop results in a spectacular nauseous depression. I always heard “corkscrew” to describe those roller coaster segments, and when that did not work in this puzzle I figured it was some “YOU HAVE TO PHYSICALLY FOLD THE CLUE IN HALF TO SEE THE THEME” kind of a thing.

Not for from wrong, it turned out.

Alan Alda riding his Spanish bear looking for gold on the llano probably knows it would take a möbius strip to achieve your theme, but you didn’t use those familiar landmarks. I had to rely on ECO, SADAT, OBOE, ASHE and IPA. Even then I was bored to tears and lost in the middle.

You win this round, non-intuitive thinking.

Thank you, Simeon! This was a thrilling ride, and I didn’t even come close to losing my lunch. There’s something extra satisfying about 41A being ‘WHETIMES’ (setting aside the loops) because when you ride a roller coaster, it is “whee!” time! (Although being 41 now myself, I have to say the big coasters hit different these days.)

This had everything I love about a Thursday puzzle!
I haven’t thought of Rama Lama Ding Dong or loop-de-loops in years! Good puzzle!

Maybe the hardest puzzle I’ve done in weeks. I had to turn autocheck on to get anything in the middle, and even a couple of the other clues would not come to me no matter how hard I stared at the crossers. 

Particularly hard for me were NEGAWATT, BAL (and sadly, I live in Florida), and OCHS. I did not get those until I gave up near the end and started entering vowels until the letter turned blue. 

Other lowlights:

What on earth does NIT have to do with scratching your head?


I have no idea what a madrasa is or why ISLAM would be covered in it. 

What the hell is a NOB, and what is its relation to bean or noodle?

Does TCBY even exist? The only one I know of closed down when I was a kid, so that one was especially dastardly because I also had to iterate through letters to get it. 

RAMA LAMA DING DONG was too hard to get the specific letters if you couldn’t get the crossers. I kept thinking of the other stupid nonsense song that goes something like, “Oooh, eeee, oooh-ah-ah, ting tang, walla-walla-bing-bang,” so that one was especially difficult without knowing the right reference. 

STN is almost always abbreviated to STA in the crossword, so that didn’t help with NEGAWATT until I turned on autocheck. 

MASALAS makes sense, but crossed with too many hard-to-get words. 

No idea who Juliette LEWIS is. 

MYMAN wasn’t coming until I turned on autocheck. 

Ditto ASANA. What is that?  Never heard of it. 

Don’t even feel bad. Never solving this without autocheck.

I love roller coasters but draw the line at ones with loops, refusing to be turned upside down, inside out, and 'round and 'round: (https://youtu.be/F1ehMxQdCtQ?feature=shared) I'll leave Mr. Seigel's puzzle to do that to me. And boy, this certainly was a wild roller-coaster ride. It made me feel a bit loopy and was the cause of some head-scratching, but no nits. Beautifully done, Mr. Seigel! Thank you!

I was not tall enough to ride this ride. 





cc: emu handler

Rebuses hard?  Don't be silly, it's a puzzle like this one that is hard.  The crosses seemed so obscure that even the certainties seemed doubtful.

That said, amid the stonewalls , e.g. TCBY? (we don't have that here) there were some sweet clues tucked in—found Prepare for a kiss easier when I just LEANED IN, but all in all, the whole project was just MESSY for me, and I spent far more time solving it than I had to spare. 

You're a very clever fellow, Simeon Seigel, but next time they tell you that you've created a Thursday puzzle, just say no and hold out for a Saturday, which is where this one belonged.  

Still, I do appreciate your wit, and thank you for all the work that must have gone into this Peak of Revelation. (Next time I see your name, I'll be ready.)
Took a month to have a really bad puzzle in 2024, but this one fills the bill from foreign words requiring nothing but guess work to a simpleton theme.  February flop, in short.

I couldn’t see the circles until I updated to v4.64.00 on iPhone. But here’s the thing: my phone (and I assume many/most others) are set to auto-update all apps. Whenever this crucial update came out, it was still in the auto-update queue on my phone along with many other apps. Life in our times.

So this is a NYT tech fail. Don’t publish a puzzle that needs to run on the latest update until well after the latest update has been released and installed on your subscribers’ devices! 🤦
This was neat, I loved it. Super satisfying when I figured out what was going on.
Oof, this one was a HEAD TRIP, or maybe my brain just has a SOFT EDGE. Either way, I said AW GEE, I guess I have to LEAN IN and get MESSY.
I did it. Liked it. But I don’t understand spidey sense. Can someone explain?

Absolutely loved this puzzle. Major kudos to the constructor!

I am grateful to have never run into technical issues using the app—Android/Google Pixel—because the issue described by many iOS users (missing visual clue overlays until force-updating the app) sounds incredibly frustrating.

Please help me understand two clues:

Cultured dessert option: TCBY. No idea what's going on here.

And

Cue preceder: PEE

Peecue? PQ? Nothing makes sense to me here.

So as an Aussie living in the U.K., sometimes I struggle with the Americanisms but can someone please explain to me 40A what’s a PEE CUE? I’ve just got into these crosswords, and really enjoying them, although I get stumped a lot! Some things just don’t translate easily across the pond.
Didn't finish. The circles appeared just fine, but so too did the various unpleasantly obscure clues.

App wants to be updated, but the new version no longer supports ios 15, which is the last version availabie on the timeless iPhone SE I use around the house. I know old tech can't be supported forever, but does this update really need a version lockout?
I call Natick on 25A and 29D. TCBY, BAL.  Of course, sETTLE didn’t help with that area.

This was a real “wow” Thursday for me. 

I may have actually said “wow” when the theme clicked (which, surprisingly, didn’t take long even though it felt pretty complex, in the moment).

And I also may have chuckled out loud (COL?) when I entered RAMA LAMA DING DONG

Really enjoyed this one. SIMEON SEIGEL is becoming a favorite constructor of mine -  I haven’t forgotten the confetti puzzle on NYE. 

Mr. Seigel ushered in January with a doozy and now he’s done the same for February. Let’s make this a monthly thing. Amazing work - thank you!

"You said there'd be roller coasters!"
"No, I said I'd keep you in the loop."
"I've been taken for a ride!"

(Admission impossible.)

A bit irked by the Natick of TCBY and BAL, nearly impossible for anyone not from the USA, so I had to brute force it. 

Other than that I flew through the puzzle. Got the revealer right away, and then the theme clues made sense. Had to step away for a couple of hours and come back due to a tricky NE corner, but with a fresh set of eyes, it all fell into place. All in all, can't complain with a time of 20 min, 12 min under average (I don't know where to check personal bests, but this must be close).

Those theme answers were a thing of beauty: many times I mentally looped de looped them as I was doing the puzzle.

Learned a few things along the way like NOB and Madrasa (as well as the aforementioned TCBY). 

Favourite clues were the clever ones:
SINAI, ALI BABA, PGA TOUR, CRASH, SPIDEY and CROSS (which made me chuckle). 

All in all, a fun puzzle!

I really enjoyed the puzzle but didn't finish due to the Naticky crossing of TCBY and BAL and - to a lesser extent - the crossing of TAJ and JAMON.

But the pluses definitely outweighed the minuses.

Perfect timing!  When there was nothing left to fill in except the sections that baffled me, the iPad app had a message pop up, “there is a newer version of this, do you want to update now?”  No, I thought, I’ll wait until I finish. When there was only the M in MYMAN left to fill in, I updated it.  Okay, I worked several archived puzzles earlier in the evening, why didn’t it pop up then?

Loved the puzzle, finished without the overlay, was baffled, read what was going on here, checked for updates for my iPhone and my iPad, there were none, but then later got a prompt to update the app on my iPhone, at which point the circle appeared. I have the automatic updates on, and the show overlay on. While I enjoyed the puzzle, I would’ve enjoyed it more with the circles and the comprehension they would have produced!

The one that I remained baffled by is NOB for bean or noodle. Anyone help a feller out?

As I was filling in the theme answers, I couldn't believe they were working out like they did. Great construction! This was so much more rewarding than yesterday's theme that had no purpose. (But then again, I don't have an iPhone and I didn't get stuck on any Naticks.)
Awesome puzzle. I'm officially a Simeon Seigel fan even though I've never heard of TCBY. Don't think we had them on the west coast.

Great construction! Fun puzzle.
And it worked perfectly well on my Android. Just saying.

This Can't Be Yogurt had a bit of an odd clue. I've also known TCBY as a moniker for Elvis, Tennessee Country BoY. 

When I come across a xwp like this, I know I am getting my money's worth.

Great puzzle, and really cool theme. I see a lot of NIT picking about this and that, and I’m kind of surprised for a lot of them. There was a time in the US when it seemed like there could be more TCBY shops than people: it was the subject of jokes.

And no complaints about THREEPIO? I’m not a Star Wars fan, but I still got the answer fairly quickly, but how to spell it? That had me scratching my head, although frankly I was itchy because I was wearing a hair NeT…

Anyway that cost me about five minutes at the end, which was a buzzkill.

Wheeeeee!  That was fun!  I always love a Simeon Seigel puzzle, and this was no exception.  It wasn't one of the tough, pull my hair out Thursdays that I love, but it was terrific in its own way.  The theme even gave me JAMON, OCHS, and SEC, which I was not 100% certain of.

And no, Simeon, you are not the only one who found your original clues for 61 A and 33 A amusing.  They cracked me up!  Thank you for brightening my morning.

According to the Discogs database, RAMA LAMA DING DONG was originally released as LAMA RAMA DING DONG but the error was soon corrected. The original version with the misspelling commands a premium and Discogs considers it the Master Release as it came first.

I enjoyed your puzzle, Simeon, but would have enjoyed it more if your original clues had been used.  “A Hindu deity, a Buddhist monk, and a doorbell,” would have worked in Johnny Carson’s The Magnificent Carnac bit.  One NIT for the editors: my clue for 51 D was written “Sects’ symbol” not “Sect’s symbol” as in Deb’s write up.  Since these things matter in crosswords, that nit had me scratching my head.

Comment for NYT Games App: Thanks for the blinking “info” heads-up about viewing the puzzle today. However the issue is again with the dark-mode option where any extra markings, like the circles today, are very hard to see (even in the updated app). 

Could the app put those markings in light blue or white while in dark mode? Thanks. 

Otherwise great fun puzzle!

Yeah! 

At the end of the school year our middle school eight graders got to go on a day trip to La Ronde, and amusement park in Montreal. Chaperone assignments were a hot ticket, so parents would get their names in to volunteer early in the year. I got to go on all the roller coasters, including probably two or three LOOPDELOOPS, one hanging and one standing, so you can count me as a ride enjoyer.

I just beat my Thursday average by a couple of minutes, but I enjoyed it immensely. The major traps for me were curries before MASALAS and pucker before LEANIN, so they needed to be fixed before I could get the whole thing done.

Well done, and thanks.

Beautiful puzzle.

Love that the theme was solid, but also
that the clueing were also Thursday level.

Sometimes, the theme forces the fill to take
a backseat to make it possible to construct, 
but not today!

Solid, fun ride!!

Didn't like this puzzle. Forward loop? Backward Loop? 

Too hard, no fun. Didn't finish. Sorry

Admire the skill of the people who built it but its not for me. 

Moving on

Even with the circles I found this very difficult, so have a lot of sympathy for those who didn’t get them.  

Very impressive construction, and for me quite a struggle, needed lots more help than usual for a Thursday, but not a problem for me.  

I always enjoy seeing my favorite tennis player. (7 down)
Super easy for a Thursday (for me). I really enjoyed the loop-de-loops -- surely not easy to construct! The only holdup for me (for a few minutes) was thinking "Resolve" was SETTLE...but it's METTLE.

I’m looking at my final puzzle with that occasional mix of frustration and admiration reserved for good NYT puzzles. The loops would have made this hard, especially RAMALAMADINGDONG, a song that at least I recall hearing, but barely. But being stubborn about “inland” rather than INAFIX (and I still feel that’s a cheat, because the fair clue is ‘up A creek’) and “settle” rather than METTLE (a fair misdirect), plus learning NEGAWATT and JAMON for the first time today. Bottom line, I am glad I took the ride.

Whew. And Wow. Tough one for me, but ended up being an enjoyable workout. Really amazed when I finally tumbled to the trick, but even then figured I'd probably have something wrong when I finished and hoped I'd be able to find it. Much to my surprise - had it all right. Just an amazing feat of construction. 

First answer history search today was inspired by the other OCHS. With a bit of pondering, noted that CIRCLEOFFRIENDS is 15 letters and...
ASMALLCIRCLEOFFRIENDS is 21 letters. 

That last one sounds like a possible reveal for a tricky puzzle, but it's never been an answer. 

The first one, however, led me to my puzzle finds today. I'll put those in a reply. 

..

I am not sure what the complaints about iOS are. The NYTGames app worked completely satisfactorily in version 4.63, that is the one that had been current for some time. Even on my seven plus year old iPad whose iOS cannot be upgraded to the required level for version 4.64. Possibly some of you have been using even older versions without problems until now.

Step 1: Solve puzzle in a minute above average time, even though I didn’t understand the whole circle thing (solving from my iPhone). 
Step 2: Read the first part of the column to figure out the conceit. 
Step 3: Look back at the puzzle, still not figuring out the gimmick. 
Step 4: Go back to the column, finding the graphic that shows how it works. 
Step 5: Go back to the puzzle. I think I finally see it. Shrug. 
Step 6: Read comments to learn that there should’ve been a circle on the grid. 
Step 7: Resigned sigh. Even bigger shrug.
My iPhone kept prompting me to update the app and I stubbornly kept pushing “later” - can’t you see I’m solving here?  Only later did I realize the update would have given me the circles.
What does "whetimes" mean?  This is the answer to *"Eventually ..."?
Taken for a ride there with TCBY.

I enjoyed this puzzle a lot more than Wednesday's. The theme was trickier but the fill was more on my wavelength and solvable with crosses. 

Had a few snags (settle/mettle, sta/stn) but working with the crosses unraveled them. 

"Character with a famous opening line?" was a great clue.  :)
That was fun.
Just want to tip my hat to Mr. Joel Fagliano  for his monthly bonus puzzle (This month's theme is All About Rom-Coms). An easy puzzle but it was fun to solve. Thanks Joel

My first impression after finishing, honestly, was that this was one of those puzzles that sacrificed fill and enjoyment for aesthetics and cleverness but when I gave it another look I confess it was rather one of those times when I wasn’t immediately in synch with the creator and that’s on me. While maybe not the most sparkling entries or clueing, really there’s nothing to find fault with, and in the meantime you can’t deny the feat of find three theme clues with two loop de loops that were symmetrical and still allowed a decent grid. So bravo on that! Incidentally I didn’t get a notice about updating the app until about half way through, and I didn’t think it was entirely necessary—I had already solved loopdeloop and the first theme, and while it helped to know the placement I think I would have solved it all without.

Loved it. Circles only appeared this morning, we’re not visible last night, and that made the difference

Sign of a good puzzle is the hate mail
This was good fun!
No circles on the iPhone.

I'm glad that someone at the NYT finally fixed the circles issue, or else we'd be looking at 500 comments today, 400 of which were about how the formatting didn't work.

Instead, we only have about 100 comments of that sort, and I assume they're going to trail off as morning solvers have no issue.

Very clever puzzle. Bravo. I like to do the puzzles on my phone at night before going to sleep, and couldn't figure out the pattern because I didn't see the circles; however, this morning on the computer, all was clear to me.

Simeon: Did the editors tell you why they nixed “Doo-wop refrain incorporating a Hindu deity, a Buddhist monk and a doorbell”?  I cannot imagine a good reason.  And with your clue, one did not need to remember the Edsels.   (I remember the 50s, I remember the song, and I remember the car.  But the band? Nope.)

Circles appeared properly 
in the Newspaper Version PDF last night ... 
and in the newspaper this morning. 

No programming issues in those formats.




And I enjoyed the ride.

This was a horrible puzzle.   The overall idea isn’t bad, but one of the theme answers is a song with a nonsense name that peaked at number 21 in 1961.  And since it basically crosses itself, the crosses aren’t so much help.  How are solvers expected to get that?  That’s totally unfair. And to make up for the mess in the middle with this clue, you had early week clueing for lots of the other non theme fill making the puzzle a mixture of boring and the above mentioned bad fill.

Terrific puzzle, super clever - loved it. 
(No technical issues for me last night on iPhone, phew)

Late puzzle find, but... ...probably a day early. Just one of the most amazing puzzles I've ever encountered, and as I said, a day early, but afraid I might forget by tomorrow. Anyway - a Thursday from February 2, 1995 by Bob Klahn and Sharon Klahn. Will just note that 1 down is: PUNXSATAWNEYPHIL, which is 16 letters in an otherwise 15 x 15 puzzle. And... there's no rebus in it. You have see it to get it. Just brought a big smile to my face. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/2/1995&g=1&d=D ..
At first my IPhone had no circles in the grid. Then, midway through the puzzle an IOS message popped up notifying me about a Puzzles app update . I did the update and then the circles appeared.

This was a fantastic theme! It wasn't difficult to decipher either, which I always appreciate it. The right level of difficulty for a Thursday at 22 minutes for me, mostly from the center. RAMALAMADINGDONG was kind of rough, it was played for me as a child so I came up with the title without too much trouble but I don't know if it's quite well known enough for the crossword.

Pretty extraordinary, really challenging.  As is is often the case, I'm somewhat in awe at the vision and creativity it takes to design something like this.  Once I figured out the theme, about 15 minutes in, the rest eventually fell.  When all the squares were filled in, something was still amiss.  These days I'm too lazy to flyspeck, so when I hit "check puzzle" I realized I was stuck on one incorrect way to interpret "resolve".  I don't know what I thought "SYMAN" was for the cross going down, but I eventually realized my error.

Sorry to hear about the app issues that some had. Such a shame on this amazing piece of construction.

I usually have overlays off (for the extra challenge 🤓) and turn them on at the end of a puzzle that has something cute to show (like the recent whac-a-mole puzzle 😊). I must have forgot to turn them back off after that puzzle, and boy am I glad I did!  While I’m sure the puzzle could be solved without the circles, It would have taken some amazing intuition to figure out how the themers were working without them.

I started this last night, when the app wasn’t showing the circles. Once I got the revealer, I figured out the trick in a few spots. But I expected the loops to all go up from the starred clues’ answers, so RAMA LAMA DING DONG (a questionable entry under any circumstances, due to its age and total lack of importance) and WHEN THE TIME COMES were almost impossible to figure out. 

I went to bed having spent almost 20 minutes on the puzzle, and I had about 10 squares unfilled. 

This morning, the circles were there and helped me finish up. But a typo or two or three took forever to find. I eventually cleared the grid and retyped everything.

It’s a shame Mr. Siegel’s clever idea was ruined (at least for me) by the bad programming. I did enjoy clues like the one for ALI BABA, but I’d have enjoyed it so much more if the trick hadn’t been nearly impenetrable.

I once rode a roller coaster with not one but three loops. That was when I was young and YOLO-embracing. The last amusement park ride I tried, when my kids were little, was a humble Ferris wheel. I had to curl into a fetal position and practice deep breathing to get through the ordeal. 

This puzzle was definitely a thrilling ride, but I did it mostly circle-less (before finally checking the note) and just barely limped to the finish. Thanks for the brain workout, Mr. Seigel!

I rarely criticize puzzle clues or answers so before I start to do so, will someone please explain 25A and why 'resolve' yields METTLE as opposed to SETTLE.  I really hope someone provides a good answer because the rest of the puzzle was a joy to resolve.

I do not think that “this that and the other” means what the constructors think, unless the US definition is different to the classic British definition of it being: “several different thing”  - which clearly does not contemplate a little bit of everything.

The hardest  part was finding the stars for the theme-clues.  
I'm not lying!
Eye-drops, glasses off, plus my Weakened Condition ...but it got sorted, and (even as I thought to  myself, "Is that the screaming over this puzzle that I'm hearing?") I was just having  The Best Time!  
(Messed up sinuses, messed up ears, sheesh.)
I'm not going to be patient with anyone who maligns this puzzle or posts a rant.  This was just Genius Plus.

Adolph OCHS, eh?
IPA is "hoppy?"  No wonder I don't like it too much.
Had never thought about a synonym for METTLE... not totally satisfying, but okay with 'resolve'
Famous opening words? ABRACADABRA (was devastated when that didn't take) ...Reread the clue; then for some reason mixed up the tales and tried to shoehorn ALADDiN in there (Bzzt!) but after another attack of sneezing, coughing, blowing (sorry) my mind cleared and dear old ALi BABA made his appearance.  
Thanks ever so much, Simeon Seigel.  Wow.

I’m on an iPhone and had no technical issues with the circles. User error on the other hand …. 😹 I could not get how the loops worked and had to solve with just the crosses. I like the concept though - a nice change from rebuses.

Got the theme! Should lead to an easy solve for the rest of the puzzle right? Right?! Nope. Still liked the theme. 

Stared at TOOOLD for a while it's Too Old for anyone else like me who struggled to see it as two words. Laughed once I saw it. 

Can anyone explain Pee? The answer not the necessity of the bodily function.

Tough puzzle for me. See you on Monday Barry!

in addition to the near impossibility of figuring out the loopy clues there were other very difficult to understand ones such as cultured dessert? I have never heard of that brand, or resolve, "settle" seemed like the best fit, or "myman" -what? so an all around tough nut to crack.

I haven't finished the puzzle yet, but I had to come here to say I just had the biggest Aha! moment of my crossword solving life.  Wow!  Pure genius.  

Now back to our regular scheduled solving, already in progress.

Nice work, and I especially enjoyed the original clue for the goofy song. As you may recall

A one-L lama, he's a priest.
A two-L llama, he's a beast.
But I would bet a silk pajama

Though it is true that we use ASANA to describe all kinds of yoga poses, the clue about sitting poses is actually hinting (I would guess deliberately) at the word’s origin: asana is from Sanskrit, meaning “a sitting down.”

One-word clues such as “resolve” are regularly cited by frustrated solvers here as “vague” and “annoying,” when such clues are the delight of true puzzlers. Read as a verb, it must be “settle”; read as a noun, it must be “mettle.” The only way to resolve it is through the crossing. Crosswords do that, they test your mettle.

In Mendon, MA, there's a place called Southwick's Zoo. It's a not very small zoo in the woods that has been there for 60 years or so, and it's a really neat place. I would go to it when I was a kid, when it was called Southwick's Wild Animal Farm.

When you walk in and down to the intersection of a few walking paths, there's a little white shed with a few steps on either side that lead to little windows in the shed walls. Around the shed are signs proclaiming that the Great Red Bat, which can be seen in the shed, is a dangerous animal, no pictures, etc.

So, when I was little and saw the shed for the first time, I was really excited to see the bat. I walked up the steps, peeked in the little window, and was struck by two emotions at the same time - bitter disappointment because all that was in the shed was a red whiffle ball bat hanging from chains, and delight at the word play. But mostly disappointment.

Shed's still there, at least last time I went maybe 8 years ago, when I introduced my son to the bat. Also disappointed.

Everyone saying SETTLE/METTLE tripped them up. The issue in that area for me was TCBY. I looked it up and there are only ~10 That Can't Be Yogurt locations all only in suburbs of the tri-state area. To me, that's a huge stretch to expect almost anyone to know, especially on an acronym answer. If I had known that I could have gotten MY MAN and in turn been more confident about METTLE. Thankfully I landed on a solve by getting it down to the final letter and trying the whole alphabet.

Starting out with a once-over and not getting anything until the SE corner, I was mumbling curse words under my breath. Then little by little, quicker than I imagined, half the theme answers came, then the revealer, and it wasn't until the very end, when I completed it by changing non-PC to NOTPC and "settle" to METTLE did I look it over thoroughly and realize what a brilliant piece of construction it is.

I enjoyed the loop de loop element - very clever construction. Too bad that there seems to have been some technical difficulty in rendering it for the mobile screen.

I raise my eyebrows at a few of the clues/answers: in particular, "TCBY" for "cultured dessert option" at 27A is a business I've never heard of, maybe simply because of regional specificity or coincidence, and the lack of an indication that it was an initialism threw me for a loop (ha). Is it because it's the name of the business that the initialism isn't clued? In either case, it felt like a bit of a stretch.

Also, "THREEPIO" at 36D, while not too hard to get from the clue, is as others have pointed out both an abbreviated and non-standard spelling of the character's name which stood out to me as a little "messy." 

I felt in the end that the execution of the looping gimmick was prioritized over the elegance of some clues/answers. A notable exception was SETTLE/METTLE which several others have mentioned - this got me as well and struck me as very clever. Overall I enjoyed the puzzle and thank the constructor.
